page.title: 04KERBECK PONIES LAMPLUGH
page.content: The stables have been going for about three and a half years. Disabled riding has been going two and a half years. The stables open for riding at ten o'clock in the morning, but the woman in charge gets up at half past seven in the morning to feed the horses. This is the food, horse and pony nuts, bran, dried cornflakes, stud cubes. There are twenty horses, so two people come full time and four more at the weekends to help. These are the the sorts of horses that they keep, Fell ponies, New Forest, part Arab and Welsh. They only use fell ponies for riding. Each pony has it's own saddle and bridle. If a pony wears a different saddle or bridle it will hurt them. There are twenty different routes for the treks. Horses retire at the age of fifteen to twenty, some work longer, it depends on the horse.
